title: Neurons And Intelligence: A Birdbrained Perspective
summary:
Key ideas:
- Brain size relative to body is not the only factor in determining intelligence
- The encephalization quotient (EQ) is a useful indicator but not perfect in predicting intelligence
- Birds have high intelligence despite having small brains and a different brain structure than mammals
- Number of cortical neurons may be one of the most important biological substrates of intelligence
- Quick and efficient neural communication is also important
- Pilot whales may be smarter than humans based on their cortical neuron count

Key learnings:
- Number of neurons in the brain may be a better predictor of intelligence than brain size relative to body
- The neocortical structure may not be necessary for high intelligence, as is demonstrated in birds

Key questions:
- What is the physiological basis for intelligence?
- Can we develop a generalized animal IQ test?
- Are there other variations within species that impact intelligence other than number of neurons and neural communication?
